subject: the biology of a hand
raw:
Phalanges. <[silence]> Metacarpals. <[silence]> Ligaments. <[silence]> Tendons. <[silence]> Nerves. <[silence]> 

The human hand consists of 27 bones. <[silence]> These include 8 carpal bones, 5 metacarpal bones, and 14 phalanges. <[silence]> The carpal bones form the wrist. <[silence]> Metacarpals connect the wrist to the fingers. <[silence]> Phalanges are the bones of the fingers. <[silence]> 

Ligaments connect bones to other bones. <[silence]> Tendons attach muscles to bones. <[silence]> Flexor tendons allow bending of the fingers. <[silence]> Extensor tendons enable straightening. <[silence]> 

The hand is innervated by three main nerves: median, ulnar, and radial. <[silence]> The median nerve controls thumb opposition. <[silence]> The ulnar nerve manages fine motor skills. <[silence]> The radial nerve facilitates wrist extension. <[silence]> 

Three related subjects are the anatomy of the wrist, the physiology of grip strength, and neural pathways in the arm. <[silence]>
clean: Phalanges.  Metacarpals.  Ligaments.  Tendons.  Nerves.  The human hand consists of 27 bones.  These include 8 carpal bones, 5 metacarpal bones, and 14 phalanges.  The carpal bones form the wrist.  Metacarpals connect the wrist to the fingers.  Phalanges are the bones of the fingers.  Ligaments connect bones to other bones.  Tendons attach muscles to bones.  Flexor tendons allow bending of the fingers.  Extensor tendons enable straightening.  The hand is innervated by three main nerves: median, ulnar, and radial.  The median nerve controls thumb opposition.  The ulnar nerve manages fine motor skills.  The radial nerve facilitates wrist extension.  Three related subjects are the anatomy of the wrist, the physiology of grip strength, and neural pathways in the arm.
